awd_titl_txt: Achieving Molecular Level Control Over the Chemical, Electrochemical, and Electrical Properties of Crystalline Si Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Nathan S. Lewis of California Institute of Technology is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Division of Chemistry to study the changes in the reactivity of technologically important semiconductor surfaces that accompany the transition from small molecules to nanocrystals and two-dimensional materials, as well as from nanocrystals and two-dimensional materials to bulk crystalline solids.  The aim is to gain fundamental insight into the transition in behavior from materials comprised of individual bonds to materials formed by extended one-, two-, and ultimately three-dimensional bonding.  The project promotes the progress of science by developing novel reaction pathways that exploit the size-dependent changes in surface reactivity.  Si surfaces, small-molecule models of Si surfaces, and Si nanocrystals are selected as a critical example to provide insight into the chemical continuum from the nanoscale to the macroscale.  The novel reaction pathways being developed may enable a new generation of solar cells, new interfaces for sensors and electronic devices and new approaches to other related Si device constructs.  Graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds are involved in the project.  In addition, the research results are incorporated into Freshmen chemistry course material, integrated in outreach program towards high schools, such as Juice from Juice and Project SEAL hands-on science modules, and communicated to non-professional audiences at all levels and through multiple media outlets.       

In this project, new classes of reactions that are enabled by changes in the electronic structure of semiconductors that result from changes in the size and dimensionality of the material are explored.    The project is focused on determining: 1) which classes of reactions are influenced by the underlying electronic structure of the solid, 2) whether such reactions can be used to systematically achieve beneficial electronic coupling between nanoparticles, and, 3) whether such reactions can be used to covalently link three-dimensional materials, such as bulk crystals, to two-dimensional materials while also providing control over the electronic coupling of the structurally dissimilar materials.  The scope of the project includes reactions on Si surfaces, small-molecule models of Si surfaces, and Si nanocrystals.  The project also includes reactions on two-dimensional materials such as graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition-metal chalcogenides anchored to Si surfaces.  This project is also developing methods to covalently functionalize two-dimensional materials, such as graphene, to allow robust electronic connections and strong interactions between layers and in heterojunction stacks.  Functionalized two-dimensional materials are being attached to linkers covalently bonded to the Si surface, and more layers are being added to the stack using sequential addition of layers and linkers until the behavior approximates that of the bulk material on Si, as determined by XPS and optical characterization methods.  This work is developing an understanding of the point at which stacks of two-dimensional materials begin to behave in the same was as bulk materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of the NSF supported work was to develop new, powerful methods of chemically modifying the properties of silicon (Si) surfaces, and to develop structure-function relationships for such surfaces. Chemically modified Si surfaces are important for many applications including: interfacing molecular electronics to Si-based circuitry, developing novel chemical sensors, developing new integrated optoelectronic devices, improving the efficiencies of photovoltaic and photoelectrochemical cells, increasing the photoelectrochemical stability of Si devices under operational conditions, and enabling high efficiencies from novel devices constructed from inexpensive but high surface area materials. By correlating the chemical state of modified Si surfaces with changes in the electrical, physical, and electronic characteristics of such surfaces, the work provided direction for the development of semiconductor materials with desired application-specific properties, enabled by virtue of molecular-level control over the chemistry of the Si surface. 

            A major outcome of the work was the development of a reductant-activated chemistry to add electrophilic organic species to Si surfaces, including substrates with multiple functional groups attached. This synthetic route afforded fine molecular control, ensuring that only type of binding mode was established, thus expanding the scope of and atomic-level precision with which molecules can be added to Si surfaces. The reaction chemistry requires relatively short reaction times and occurs at room temperature, without need for specialized equipment such as a microwave reactor, providing a much milder surface functionalization route compared to other established methods in the field. We showed that surface coverage was a function of the reductant strength (redox potential). Stronger reductants yielded greater coverage. Moreover, we expanded this chemistry to successfully functionalize Si nanocrystals (Si NCs). Si NCs can exhibit quantum confinement effects and resulting in size-dependent, tunable optical properties. Si NCs are a non-toxic and biocompatible. Si NCs can prepared via simple wet-chemical methods, in contrast to single Si crystal wafers that require highly controlled processing to generate. Functionalization of Si NCs can impart protection from oxidation, tune the optical properties, and tailor solubility.

            A second significant outcome of this work was successful surface functionalization of single-crystalline Si with organic moieties that may be applied to improve the efficiency as well as the durability of solar energy conversion devices that utilize sunlight to generate hydrogen fuel via a photoelectrochemical process. Specifically, we specifically functionalized Si surfaces with mixed monolayers containing 4-trifluoromethylphenylacetylene (TFMPA) and methyl groups.

             This project has provided training and professional development opportunities for a diverse group of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. In addition, several undergraduates have participated in this project.  Through this project, NSF has provided opportunities for research and teaching experience and mentoring in chemistry that will contribute to the development and retention of a workforce skilled in chemistry that includes members of groups historically underrepresented in the physical sciences. Additionally, graduate students have participated in several activities to improve the scientific community at large including the Solar Energy Activity Lab (SEAL). SEAL is a local program that engages high school students in high-throughput experimentation to discover acid-stable catalysts for water oxidation.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2023
Modified by: Nathan S Lewis
